Award.AwardTitle: EFRI 2-DARE: Valley Optoelectronics with Atomically Thin Transition Metal Dichalcogenides
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: This project is aimed at exploiting the novel electronic and optical properties of two-dimensional (2D) materials through the use of a unique set of devices built at the nanometer scale. The main strategy is to implement new techniques to control the quantum mechanical behavior of electrons in 2D materials by tuning how they interact with photons of light as well as with precise electrical signals. The optoelectronic devices explored in this project have the potential to improve high-speed data communications and low-power electronics in a transformative way. This project provides an ideal framework for multidisciplinary education, where physics and engineering students in different research areas can interact closely with each other. The project also partners with existing programs at Berkeley (such as the Berkeley Edge program) that are aimed at enhancing the recruitment and training of underrepresented and woman students engaged the frontier research in science and engineering.

Technical Description: This EFRI 2-DARE project aims to develop novel valleytronic and optoelectronic devices based on atomically thin transition metal dichalcogenide (MX2) crystals. Owing to their reduced dimensionality and high spin-orbital coupling, two-dimensional MX2 crystals (where M is a transition metal and X is a chalcogen) exhibit unusual quantum phenomena, including unique exciton physics and emergent valley degrees of freedom. An outstanding scientific question concerns the interplay between photons, excitons, and charge carriers with different valley and spin states in 2D MX2 crystals. This project aims at obtaining fundamental understanding of such interplay, and at developing novel valleytronic and optoelectronic devices based on these new insights. These goals will be achieved through an interdisciplinary and highly integrated approach that combines expertise in materials synthesis, spectroscopic characterization, device engineering, and theoretical modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Traditional electronics rely on the motion of electron charge to transport, store, and process information. However, fundamental limits of electronic devices have prompted scientists to look for alternative strategies that use other properties of electrons to carry information. One particularly exciting strategy involves the valley pseudospin, which describes the momentum states that an electron or hole can occupy and can be thought of as an additional binary property of charge carriers. This new field of “valleytronics” promises energy-efficient technologies based on the transport of valley pseudospin. Atomically-thin transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs), a family of two dimensional (2D) semiconductors, form a promising platform for valleytronic devices because valley-polarized excitations can be conveniently generated and manipulated with circularly-polarized light.

Over the lifetime of this project, we have investigated the properties of atomically-thin TMDCs for novel valley optoelectronics applications. We have made comprehensive and systematic efforts towards investigating TMDCs and other related 2D crystals to understand their electronic, magnetic, and optoelectronic properties. From these efforts, we have unveiled exciting new fundamental physical properties of TMDCs and realized novel device applications based on the materials. Further, this project has inspired important discoveries of exotic states of matter in TMDCs and progress on materials synthesis and processing.

In TMDCs, the valley degree of freedom is particularly interesting because it is coupled to spin and can be selectively excited by circularly-polarized light. In this project, we have demonstrated several interesting and technologically-useful electronic and optical valley phenomena. For example, we have demonstrated the ability to electronically generate a valley polarization in TMDCs via spin injections from ferromagnetic materials. We have also demonstrated optical generation, transport, and imaging of long-lived valley currents in stacks of TMDC, which can propagate over tens of microns. Further, we have reported the first observation of moiré superlattice exciton states in nearly aligned TMDC stacks, which shows that this natural superlattice is a powerful tool to engineer novel quantum phenomena and the valley degree of freedom. These results show significant progress towards the realization of valleytronics.

In addition, we have made important discoveries regarding exotic phases of matter in TMDCs. To start, we have discovered the existence of isolated, one-dimensional charge density waves (CDWs) at mirror twin boundaries of single-layer semiconducting MoSe2. We have also experimentally confirmed theoretical predictions that the 1T' phase of single-layer TMDCs is a quantum spin Hall insulator. Additionally, we characterized single-layer 1H-TaSe2 using angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, scanning tunneling microscopy, and density functional theory calculations. We demonstrated that CDW order persists despite distinct changes in the low energy electronic structure, which provides a deeper understanding of the nature of CDW order in the two-dimensional limit.

A commitment to understanding TMDCs and their use in valleytronics has also required significant progress in materials synthesis and processing. A significant challenge towards widespread usage of TMDCs is the difficulty in growing large-scale, high-quality, atomically-thin films. Under this award, we have learned to grow MoS2 over large areas with seamless integration with graphene, another 2D material. After fabrication and deposition of electrodes on the graphene-MoS2 heterostructure, we observe excellent transistor behavior across over a hundred devices in various metrics. This method of synthesis provides a solution to electrically contact the MoS2 and shows great potential for scalability of TMDC devices.

We have been actively involved in the dissemination of our research results to the wider scientific communities and in the outreach to the general public. We have published our findings in peer-reviewed scientific journals and posted the relevant publications on group websites. In addition to standard publication forums, we have presented our results at research opportunity workshops for undergrads and at forums for the local community (e.g., visiting teachers, "Cal Day" lab tours, alumni lab tours, tours for high school students and general community members).  We have also had extensive contact with visiting students. This includes a lab tour for high school girls (GetSET program) and for graduate students.

In summary, we have contributed and disseminated exciting results regarding electronics, optoelectronics, and exotic phases in TMDCs, which together highlight the important technological role that this family of materials will have going forward.
